TitleMain.Title: Set-up for relapse

Author.CollectiveName: GWC (Firm)

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Michael Johnson addresses the dynamics surrounding relapse and the addicted offender. He explains how many in recovery have looked at sobriety as a temporary experience, only to be engaged in while incarcerated, or on probation and parole.

Johnson addresses the dynamics surrounding relapse and the addicted criminal offender. He explains how anger, hidden motives, making deals, power struggles, making promises and being obsessed with material things are all set ups for relapse. He addresses the role of family and peer relationships, and the importance of avoiding "me too buddies." This open, in your face presentation addresses other pitfalls associated with relapse.

TitleMain.Title: Federalism and patient protection : changing roles for state and federal government
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / Jill A. Marsteller, Randall R. Bovbjerg.

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Occasional paper (Assessing the New Federalism (Program)) ; no. 28

Author.CollectiveName: Urban Institute.

Abstract.AbstractText: Assessing the New Federalism is a multiyear Urban Institute project designed to analyze the devolution of responsibility for social programs from the federal government to the states, focusing primarily on health care, income security, job training, employment and training programs, and social services. Researchers monitor program changes and fiscal developments. In collaboration with Child Trends, the project studies changes in family well-being. The project aims to provide timely, nonpartisan information to inform public debate and to help state and local decisionmakers carry out their new responsibilities more effectively. Key components of the project include a household survey, studies of policies in 13 states, and a database with information on all states and the District of Columbia, available at the Urban Institute's Web site. This paper is one in a series of occasional papers analyzing information from these and other sources.

TitleMain.Title: Gesundheitsreform : Entwicklung des Krankenversicherungsrechts über das Jahr 2000 hinaus
Implementation of managed care consumer protections in Missouri, New Jersey, Texas & Vermont : full report.

Author.OtherInformation: Georgetown University, Institute for Health Care Research and Policy, USA.

Author.CollectiveName: Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Menlo Park, CA : Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation 1999.

Abstract.AbstractText: Since 1995, many states have enacted comprehensive managed care consumer protection laws. The Medicaid and Medicare programs have also adopted significant new consumer protections. These state and federal changes have been well catalogued. Less well known, however, is what it takes to implement these legal protections effectively. This report describes the implementation of managed care consumer protections in four states: Missouri, New Jersey, Texas and Vermont. These states were selected on the basis of their geographic diversity, the comprehensiveness and unique features of their reforms, and their innovative implementation issues and approaches. Information for this study was obtained from interviews with regulators, health plans, provider groups and consumer groups in the states; analysis of laws, regulations, legislative reports, and position papers; and a review of media articles and journal literature. The research focused on the following questions in each study state: (1) What new managed care consumer protections has been passed? (2) What have been the key implementation, monitoring, and enforcement issues? (3) What has been the initial impact of the reforms on accountability and quality? The genesis of these reforms has been different in each state, and the substantive provisions vary in scope and intent, but some common themes emerge. It is not easy to put into practice legal protections to ensure "adequate" access, "appropriate" decision-making, and "quality" care by health plans. Challenges arise in defining terms, measuring compliance, minimizing regulatory burdens, and informing consumers about their protections.

TitleMain.Title: Alternative approaches to liability : models for health plan liability

Author.OtherInformation: University of the Pacific, McGeorge School of Law, USA.

Author.CollectiveName: Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Menlo Park, CA : Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, 1999.

Abstract.AbstractText: The recent, explosive growth of managed care organizations ("MCOs") has created novel legal issues involving MCO liability for patient injuries. Many of the novel issues have arisen because of federal and state laws that protect such plans from tort liability. Provisions in the federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 ("ERISA") protect most MCOs from tort suits under state law for injuries resulting from erroneous coverage decisions, and provisions in many state laws protect MCOs from suits for medical malpractice. Over the last several years, dissatisfaction with the current limitations on health plan liability for patient injuries has contributed to public pressure for legal reform of the managed care system. A range of liability models may be considered by policymakers. A contract model of liability is on one end of the continuum. The main purpose of the modern law of contracts is to permit persons and organizations privately to manage and reduce the risk of future contingencies by entering into legally enforceable agreements. The remedies for breach of contract are carefully limited so that the parties know when they enter into a contract what their potential liability may be in the event of a breach. For example, damages for emotional distress and punitive damages are generally not available for a breach of contract. The contract model of liability facilitates and encourages people to manage risks by entering into private contracts. A tort model of liability is on the other end of the continuum. Tort law reflects public policies about how people and organizations should behave with respect to each other, not just how people privately agree to behave with respect to each other. Tort liability is generally designed to deter people from engaging in wrongful or highly risky conduct and to provide compensation to persons injured by such conduct. An injured plaintiff can recover compensatory damages for all of the harm suffered by the plaintiff, and, in appropriate cases, can recover punitive damages. Along the continuum are mixed models of liability that share some of the characteristics of contracts and some of the characteristics of torts. A review of liability approaches in selected industries shows the range of possibilities. Employer liability for termination of "at will" employees is governed largely by contract doctrines. Employers' liability for workplace injuries is regulated by workers' compensation statutes, a mixed tort/contract liability approach. Tort liability has been limited in the field of medical malpractice by legislative tort reform, and in the field of drug and health care product manufacturing by judicial decisions. Tort liability without significant limitation is imposed upon manufacturing industries by the doctrine of product liability, upon professional services providers (other than physicians) by the doctrine of malpractice, and upon the insurance industry by the doctrine of bad faith breach. Proposals for reform of health care plan liability principles fall all along the continuum. Some reforms, such as proposals for independent utilization review boards to provide patients with a right of appeal from an adverse coverage decision, are consistent with a contract model of liability. Some have advocated creation of a Medical Injury Compensation Fund similar to the workers. compensation system. Other proposals would impose upon MCOs malpractice liability similar to that imposed upon medical providers, including some of the limitations on tort liability applicable to medical malpractice. Still other proposals would create essentially unlimited tort liability for MCO bad faith decision-making, similar to bad faith insurance claims.

TitleMain.Title: Point-of-care in vitro diagnostic (IVD) testing; approved guideline

Author.CollectiveName: National Committee for Clinical Laboratory Standards.

Abstract.AbstractText: Point-of-care testing (POCT), also known as bedside testing or near-patient testing, is intended to provide more rapid test results than can be achieved in central or satellite laboratory settings. This is important particularly in critical care areas such as the intensive care unit, emergency rooms, burn units, emergency transport vehicles, and operating rooms, as well as in skilled nursing facilities and hospices. POCT has also been used to expedite treatment decisions and provide convenience for the patient. This guideline provides users of in vitro diagnostic (IVD) devices outside the clinical laboratory with information and suggestions for good laboratory practice and for producing reliable test results regardless of where the test is performed.

TitleMain.Title: State HMO accreditation and external quality review requirements : implications for HMOs serving rural areas

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Rural health working paper series ; no. 27

Author.CollectiveName: University of Minnesota. Rural Health Research Center.

Abstract.AbstractText: EXECUTIVE SUMMARY: This paper is the second in a series of papers examining the relationship between accreditation and HMOs serving rural areas. The purpose of this paper is (1) to analyze state regulations regarding HMO accreditation and external quality review; (2) to discuss the implications of these regulations for HMOs serving rural areas; and (3) to briefly describe states' experiences in implementating these regulations. The primary focus is on state regulations that require an HMO to seek accreditation or undergo external quality review as a condition of licensure. A secondary focus is on state regulations or contract provisions that require an HMO to be accredited in order to serve state employees. The incorporation of HMO accreditation and external quality review requirements into state HMO licensure processes and state employee contracting raises several policy issues that are especially relevant to HMOs serving rural populations. A key issue is whether the linkage of accreditation and external quality review requirements to HMO licensure will be an additional deterrent to the development of new HMOs or the expansion of existing HMOs into rural areas. Other issues relate to the costs and benefits of accreditation for HMOs serving rural populations and the potential impact of HMO accreditation requirements on efforts to expand managed care enrollment of rural Medicaid and Medicare beneficiaries and rural state employees. Analysis of state regulations and interviews with state officials identified nine states that have regulations requiring HMOs to apply for or obtain accreditation, or to undergo an external quality review, as a condition of licensure: Florida, Kansas, Nevada, New Jersey, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, and West Virginia. Four states were identified as implementing requirements that an HMO be accredited in order to serve state employees: Alabama, Iowa, Ohio, and Tennessee. Many state HMO accreditation and external quality review requirements are still in the early stages of implementation, so there has been limited opportunity to assess their impact. As states gain more experience implementing these requirements, it will be especially important to evaluate their rural impact. Several states that have incorporated state HMO accreditation or external quality review requirements into their HMO licensure processes have significant rural populations. The states with state employee HMO accreditation requirements also have substantial rural populations. These states will provide opportunities to evaluate the impact of accreditation and external review requirements on HMOs serving rural areas, rural providers, and rural customers.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Whistle-blowers in a landmark fertility clinic bioethics case called it biomedical rape : the misappropriation of a patient's extra embryos for implantation into other unsuspecting patients. In this program CBS News correspondent Richard Schlesinger reports on the case of Debbie and John Challender, victims of the alleged medical misconduct by doctors at the University of California's prestigious Center for Reproductive Health. The Challenders and others discuss the devastating impact of that experience, as well as the dangerously under-regulated state of biotechnology.

TitleMain.Title: The proposed tobacco settlement : issues from a federal perspective

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Congressional Budget Office.

Abstract.AbstractText: On June 20, 1997, the tobacco industry reached a settlement with a number of state attorneys general who had brought suit against it. Under the agreement, tobacco companies would make substantial annual payments to state governments and others and would abide by many additional regulations, including restrictions on advertising, labeling, and access. The settlement specifies payments of $368.5 billion (in 1998 dollars) over the next 25 years, assuming no change in tobacco consumption. If consumption fell, however, the industry's payments would be reduced proportionately. In return, the agreement would place limits on future litigation against the industry and alter the Food and Drug Administration's (FDA's) authority to regulate tobacco products and smoking. Under the settlement's restrictions on litigation, no class action suits or suits by any government entity could be brought against the tobacco companies, and those companies would be immune from all punitive damage liability for past conduct. The settlement would allow only individuals to bring suits to recover compensatory damages (such as medical costs and lost wages) for past industry conduct and compensatory and punitive damages for future conduct. Implementing the agreement would require federal legislation, at a minimum, to grant the promised legal immunity to the tobacco industry and, perhaps, to modify FDA policies. The settlement targets the use of cigarettes and smokeless tobacco for reduction efforts. Cigarettes account for most of the spending on tobacco products in the United States. This paper focuses on how the settlement might reduce cigarette consumption and estimates the amount of payments that the tobacco industry would make.

TitleMain.Title: Continuity of offender treatment for substance use disorders from institution to community

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration.
Center for Substance Abuse Treatment (U.S.).

Abstract.AbstractText: EXECUTIVE SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS. It is clearly in the public interest for offenders with substance use disorders to receive appropriate treatment both in prison or jail and in the community after release. Numerous studies show that those who remain dependent on substances are much more likely to return to criminal activity. Research also indicates that treatment gains may be lost if treatment is not continued after the offender is released from prison or jail. In part, this is because release presents offenders with a difficult transition from the structured environment of the prison or jail. Many prisoners after release have no place to live, no job, and no family or social supports. They often lack the knowledge and skills to access available resources for adjustment to life on the outside, all factors that significantly increase the risk of relapse and recidivism. This TIP presents guidelines for ensuring continuity of care as offenders with substance use disorders move from incarceration to the community. The guidelines are for treatment providers in prisons, jails, community corrections, and other institutions, as well as community providers. The following recommendations are based on a combination of research and the clinical experience of the Consensus Panel that developed this TIP. Recommendations based on research are denoted with a (1); those based on experience are followed by a (2). Citations supporting the former appear in Chapters 1 through 6. References to specific programs appear throughout those chapters as well; Appendix B provides contact information for many of those model programs.

TitleMain.Title: Findings of the Pennsylvania Health Care Cost Containment Council : mandated benefits review of Senate Bill 1057
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / L. Edris, M. Volavka, F. Wolf.

Author.CollectiveName: Pennsylvania Health Care Cost Containment Council.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Harrisburg : Pennsylvania Health Care Cost Containment Council, 1998.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: Pennsylvania Health Care Cost Containment Council,

Abstract.AbstractText: After reviewing the staff analysis of Senate Bill 1057, the Mandated Benefits Review Committee of the Pennsylvania Health Care Cost Containment Council can not support this bill at this time. We were unable to find needed proof in the review of Senate Bill 1057 that coverage of bone density testing would provide corresponding savings, either in terms of saved health care dollars or improved quality of life. We conclude that, in as much as neither proponents nor opponents have submitted sufficient documentation pursuant to Act 34 of 1993, the Council did not receive the necessary and required information on the social and financial impact or the medical efficacy to warrant recommending approval of the mandated health benefits proposed under Senate Bill 1057. The Committee also concludes that there is a serious and significant need for public education regarding osteoporosis prevention. Medical professionals and experts agree that the most effective way to deal with osteoporosis is to prevent it, and education is an essential component in prevention. While the benefits of osteoporosis prevention and early detection on improved quality of life and future health care savings are indisputable, we found there to be no consensus in medical literature that broad-based osteoporosis screening via bone density testing would necessarily achieve these results. Had there been such definitive information or a consensus on the benefits of broad-based bone mineral density screening, the Committee may have concluded differently regarding recommending passage of the bill. While not required as part of mandated benefits reviews, Council staff undertook significant efforts in conducting independent research to better understand osteoporosis in general, including an examination of the Council's own hospitalization and average charge data, and the projected costs of Senate Bill 1057. Using numerous internet and library resources and by contacting state and federal personnel, staff applied some broad, and perhaps gross, assumptions to estimate that the implementation of Senate Bill 1057 could cost between $199 million and $275 million yearly. If only 50% of the eligible population would utilize the benefits mandated under the bill and undergo bone density testing in any year, the costs for the mandate could reach as high as from $99 million to $137 million per year. While staff were able to provide these broad cost estimates, no information was received or found that allowed us to estimate the potential cost savings of the measure. In addition to the conclusion that there is a need for improvement in public education and awareness of osteoporosis prevention; the Mandated Benefits Review Committee finds the following upon reviewing the staff analysis of Senate Bill 1057: (1) The Council recognizes the importance of preventing osteoporosis and is sympathetic to the burden this disease places on affected Pennsylvanians and their family members. Clearly, osteoporosis and related fractures are extremely costly to the Commonwealth in terms of direct health care expenditures, lost productivity, and diminished quality of life for Pennsylvanians--and the disease will only become more prevalent among our increasingly elderly population if current trends are not addressed; (2) We conclude, however, that neither supporters nor opponents of the bill provided sufficient information to warrant a full review of the proposal; nor, given the documentation received, do we believe a panel of experts would come to conclusions different than the ones reached here; (3) Council staff research has found there to be no universal level of bone mineral density at which osteoporosis is defined; (4) There does not appear to be sufficient proof that coverage of bone density testing actually improves preventive efforts or reduces the incidence of osteoporotic fractures; (5) We assert that using perimenopausal status as a definition for the clinical indication of bone density testing would result in very broad-based screening using metho(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED)

TitleMain.Title: The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 : its effect on PPS inpatient margins.

Author.CollectiveName: Medicare Payment Advisory Commission (U.S.).

Abstract.AbstractText: CHAPTER SUMMARY: The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (BBA) reduced anticipated federal spending by $127 billion between 1998 and 2002. The Medicare program alone accounted for $112 billion in savings over this five-year period. These savings represent a 9.1 percent reduction in total program spending, and a decrease in the annual growth rate from 8.8 percent to 5.6 percent.

Author.CollectiveName: Medicare Payment Advisory Commission (U.S.).

Abstract.AbstractText: CHAPTER SUMMARY: The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (BBA) requires risk adjusted payments to Medicare+Choice plans starting in the year 2000. This chapter looks at two major decisions the Health Care Financing Administration (HCFA) must make for the design of the risk-adjusted system.

OtherSubject.OtherSubjectName: United States. Health Care Financing Administration

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Report to Congress: Medicare payment policy. Volume II

TitleMain.Title: Prospective payment for post-acute care and excluded facilities.

Author.CollectiveName: Medicare Payment Advisory Commission (U.S.).

Abstract.AbstractText: CHAPTER SUMMARY: The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (BBA) charged the Secretary of Health and Human Services with the development of prospective payment systems (PPS) for several providers that are now paid under cost-based methods. Over the next few years, the Health Care Financing Administration (HCFA) will begin implementing such systems for home health agencies, skilled nursing facilities (SNFs), and rehabilitation facilities. The Secretary also must report on a PPS for the other major provider of post-acute care services, long-term care hospitals. Rehabilitation facilities and long-term care hospitals, as well as psychiatric facilities, children's hospitals, and cancer hospitals, were excluded from the inpatient hospital PPS because their patients and treatment patterns were so different that the acute care PPS was not appropriate for them. At this time, there are no plans to design prospective systems for psychiatric, children's, or cancer facilities.

TitleMain.Title: Prospective payment for hospital outpatient services.

Author.CollectiveName: Medicare Payment Advisory Commission (U.S.).

Abstract.AbstractText: CHAPTER SUMMARY: The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (BBA) requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to implement a prospective payment system (PPS) for hospital outpatient services beginning on January 1, 1999. The Secretary also must develop a way to control the volume of hospital services furnished under the outpatient PPS. Finally, the law defines a method for reducing beneficiaries' outpatient coinsurance liabilities commensurate with those in other settings.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Report to Congress: Medicare payment policy. Volume I

TitleMain.Title: Hospital inpatient prospective payment updates.

Author.CollectiveName: Medicare Payment Advisory Commission (U.S.).

Abstract.AbstractText: CHAPTER SUMMARY: Medicare pays for inpatient services at general acute care hospitals using predetermined per discharge payment rates developed under a prospective payment system (PPS). The PPS payment rates are updated annually to reflect anticipated changes in input prices (such as those for labor, supplies, or equipment) as well as other factors, like improvements in medical technology and growth in productivity, that are expected to affect hospitals' costs. In addition, the Congress and the Secretary of Health and Human Services frequently modify the law or regulations governing the level and distribution of payments.

TitleMain.Title: Risk adjustment.

Author.CollectiveName: Medicare Payment Advisory Commission (U.S.).

Abstract.AbstractText: CHAPTER SUMMARY: The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (BBA) requires the risk adjustment of Medicare capitation payments starting in the year 2000. The first part of this chapter explains what risk adjustment is, why it is needed in Medicare, and what options are immediately available. The second part offers recommendations for implementing risk-adjusted capitation rates for Medicare+Choice plans.

TitleMain.Title: Medicare's capitation payments to private health plans.

Author.CollectiveName: Medicare Payment Advisory Commission (U.S.).

Abstract.AbstractText: CHAPTER SUMMARY: Two major components of the Medicare reforms that became law in the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (BBA) (P.L. 105-33) were the expansion of options for private health plan participation in Medicare and a restructuring of the method for paying these plans. Options will be expanded through creation of a new Medicare+Choice program that will replace the current Medicare risk program starting in late 1998. The new method for setting capitation payments to private health plans was implemented by the Health Care Financing Administration (HCFA) with new rates that went into effect in January 1998, and further changes will be phased in through 2003.

These changes were designed to produce significant savings, expand beneficiaries' choices to a wider selection of health plan options, and strengthen the traditional Medicare program. Implementing and monitoring the effects of the BBA will present major challenges to policy makers over the next decade.

TitleMain.Title: Does work pay? An analysis of the work incentives under TANF

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Assessing the New Federalism: occasional paper ; no. 9

Author.CollectiveName: Urban Institute.

Abstract.AbstractText: Assessing the New Federalism is a multi-year Urban Institute project designed to analyze the devolution of responsibility for social programs from the federal government to the states, focusing primarily on health care, income security, job training, and social services. Researchers monitor program changes and fiscal developments. In collaboration with Child Trends, Inc., the project studies changes in family well-being. The project aims to provide timely, nonpartisan information to inform public debate and to help state and local decisionmakers carry out their new responsibilities more effectively. Key components of the project include a household survey, studies of policies in 13 states, and a database with information on all states and the District of Columbia, available at the Urban Institute's Web site. This paper is one in a series of occasional papers analyzing information from these and other sources.

TitleMain.Title: Medicaid eligibility standards for low-income families and children. State implementation of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996

Author.CollectiveName: National Association of State Medicaid Directors.
American Public Welfare Association.
Health Care Financing Administration.

Abstract.AbstractText: The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 (PRWORA, P.L. 104-193) ended the automatic link between the old AFDC (Aid to Families with Dependent Children) program and the Medicaid program. Under prior law, anyone found eligible to receive cash assistance was also enrolled in the state's Medicaid program. Under PRWORA, persons eligible for services under the new TANF (Temporary Assistance to Needy Families) program, which replaced AFDC, are not guaranteed Medicaid coverage. The states are required to find persons eligible for Medicaid if they would have been eligible under the pre-reform AFDC rules, but even here, states have the latitude to adjust those rules to some degree. How states address this new flexibility is of great interest to state and national policymakers, consumer advocates, and researchers. With this paper APWA inaugurates a series of reports intended to provide detailed information on state decisions with regard to implementation of the new Medicaid provisions. This report furnishes baseline information on each state's AFDC rules prior to implementation of PRWORA, plus data with respect to other options afforded under the new law, such as coverage of certain non-citizens. The paper is based on a survey conducted in the winter and spring of 1997, and represents state policy as of January 1, 1997. The results of a second survey, conducted in late 1997, will reflect decisions made between January 1, 1997 and January 1, 1998, after most state legislatures have had an opportunity to act on these issues. A state could implement the new TANF program as early as October 1, 1996, or as late as July 1, 1997. Because of the need for state legislative action, some of the states responding to this survey had not made final implementation decisions as of January 1, 1997. Nevertheless, the data suggest some trends that are likely to persist. (1) As of January 1997 most states used identical income and resources standards in their TANF and Medicaid programs. Only five states reported differences, and in all such instances the TANF standards were more generous. The discussion and data relating to this topic can be found in Part 1. (2) Forty-seven states and the District of Columbia use a consolidated application form for TANF and Medicaid. For more information, see Part 1, Section 1.2. (3) The new law allowed states to continue provisions of statewide welfare reform IV-A waivers in place on July 16, 1996 that affected Medicaid eligibility. Thirty-five states had such waivers. As of January 1, 1997, twenty-seven of these states reported they would continue to operate according to their waiver rules. Of the others, one state terminated its waiver, four states had never implemented their waivers, and three states were still undecided. Part 2 provides further details on this subject. (4) As of January 1, 1997, a majority of the states were continuing to offer Medicaid benefits to groups of qualified aliens for whom coverage is now optional, rather than mandatory. The data and discussion relating to aliens can be found in Part 3. By the time of publication of this report, the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 had been enacted, restoring SSI eligibility to aliens receiving SSI on August 22, 1996 and disabled aliens lawfully residing in the U.S. on August 22, 1996. Refugees and asylees are eligible for SSI and Medicaid for seven years after entering the country. (5) Fifteen states had elected to terminate Medicaid benefits for parents who failed to meet work requirements under the state's TANF program. For a state-by-state look at this option, see Part 4. A more detailed discussion of these findings and state-by-state data tables are contained in the body of this report.

TitleMain.Title: Medical device and equipment management for hospital and community-based organisations.

Author.CollectiveName: Great Britain. Medical Devices Agency.

Abstract.AbstractText: This bulletin is written primarily for people responsible for purchasing, deploying, maintaining and repairing medical devices in hospital and in the community. This will include managerial, technical, and clinical staff. Many of the decisions involved have a direct impact both on professionals and patients, and input from these groups is needed during the decision-making process. We argue for setting up broad based consultative groups to oversee both purchasing decisions and device management. The two factors with the greatest impact on device safety are training and maintenance. We stress throughout that user knowledge and skills have major implications for safety. Instructions must be clear, concise, and readily available. Training needs to be timely and effective, and include procedures for the routine maintenance of devices by users. Planned preventative maintenance, carried out following manufacturer's guidance by properly trained technicians, is the other key element in ensuring devices are safe and reliable. Users and technicians need to understand the basic principles on which devices work (generic training) as well as how to use a particular model (specific training). Training programmes should include input from manufacturers. Within the context of a general guide to good practice in the management of medical devices, we have aimed to provide balanced information for groups developing local policy in key areas, including whether: (1) to use a central pool or library, or distribute devices among clinical units; (2) to standardise on a single model; (3) to perform extensive acceptance tests on every device delivered; (4) to use a third party maintenance and repair organisation; (5) to impose administrative controls on prescribers. The medical device industry is soon to be regulated by the Medical Device Regulations, and this change increases the responsibilities of suppliers, especially with regard to the safety of products and the provision of users with adequate information. We cover the likely effects of the legislation, and summarise other legislation which impinges on the possible liabilities of healthcare organisations. This area is complicated by the growing plurality of arrangements for the supply, ownership and use of devices, which are now frequently lent or leased by suppliers, and used by unsupervised patients at home. We review possible strategies for maintaining control of devices in the community. The role of the MDA is to provide advice on purchasing, investigate adverse incidents, disseminate safety information, and to act as the UK competent authority--the regulator for the medical devices industry.

TitleMain.Title: Coma : the silent epidemic
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [videorecording] / a presentation of Films for the Humanities & Sciences ; produced by Dream Catcher Films for Discovery Channel.

Author.CollectiveName: Films for the Humanities (Firm)

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Princeton, N.J. : Films for the Humanities & Sciences, c1998.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Over 15,000 people remain in various stages of coma at any given time in the U.S. In this program, cameras enter intensive care units and rehabilitation centers to examine the condition and the methods used to treat it. Using a wide variety of case studies, doctors explain the difficulties in treating comatose patients, while family members share their anxieties about what it's like to have a loved one lingering in the minimally conscious, vegetative, or brain-dead state. Ethical issues surrounding keeping patients alive in the latter two states are discussed by family members and their doctors. In a special segment, controversial treatments such as intense stimulation and the use of the hyperbaric chamber are illustrated and discussed.

TitleMain.Title: Fetal alcohol syndrome : life sentence
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [videorecording] / a presentation of Films for the Humanities & Sciences ; produced and distributed by Canadian Broadcasting Corporation ; CBC News.

Author.CollectiveName: Films for the Humanities (Firm)

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Princeton, N.J. : Films for the Humanities & Sciences, c1998.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Fetal alcohol syndrome is the result of permanent organic injury to the brain of the fetus, caused by maternal drinking during pregnancy. That injury leads to learning disabilities, poor judgment, antisocial behavior, and worse, if a recent study is correct. This program discusses FAS within the context of that study which suggests that 20 to 25 percent of all prison inmates may suffer from the condition. The program examines how early identification and treatment of children with FAS can help prevent extreme antisocial behavior in adulthood.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Interview with Dr. Stanislaw Burzynski and two jurors the day after 32 federal charges against the doctor were dropped. Patients would come to Dr. Burzynski's clinic in Texas to be treated for cancer and would take the medicine home with them across state lines. One juror said he thought the doctor was guilty of breaking the law. The other juror believed the doctor was not guilty, since the charge was supposed to include intent to defraud, and she felt the evidence did not show that to be the case.

TitleMain.Title: FDA reform, phen/fen

Author.CollectiveName: ABC Television Network.

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Master : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (2 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videodisc of 1 (DVD) (2 min.) : sd., col. ; 4 3/4 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The Senate has passed a bill to overhaul the FDA, weakening its ability to regulate drugs and permitting it to act only after there is a problem. It is expected that this will make it easier for drug companies to promote drugs for unapproved uses. This ruling comes a week after the FDA removed phen/fen from the market, which is being cited as the worst drug disaster in the nation's history. Phen/fen is a combination of two drugs approved for use separately, but not in combination, and has been shown to cause severe heart damage when the drugs are taken together.
